Title.evidence: A Randomised Controlled Trial of Computer-Assisted Versus Conventional Total Knee Arthroplasty

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was performed at the knee level

Participants.evidence: Eligibility criteria included patients scheduled for bilateral TKA

Intervention.evidence: One knee was operated on using computer navigation, and the other without

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates whether computer-assisted total knee arthroplasty (TKA) improves clinical outcomes

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the Knee Society knee score, measured at a mean follow-up of 15 years

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed at the knee level, and allocation was concealed

Blinding.evidence: Both patients and assessors were blinded to treatment assignment

Number_Randomised.evidence: 296 patients undergoing same-day bilateral TKA were enrolled

Number_Analysed.evidence: A total of 282 patients (95%) were analysed using an intention-to-treat approach

Result_Outcome.evidence: No significant differences were found between the computer-assisted and conventional TKA groups in Knee Society knee scores (92 ± 8 vs. 93 ± 7; p = 0.461)

Harms.evidence: Anterior femoral notching occurred in 11 knees (4%) in the computer-assisted group and none in the conventional group (p = 0.046)
